image.altText: People holding umbrellas gather outside an orange terrace house with a for lease sign out the front.

items.synopsis: Property managers are often the only contact point renters have for their landlords, and agents must act in the best interests of their client. As the rental crisis continues, we take a look at who's pulling the strings.

title.children: 'I've got some very greedy landlords at the moment': Behind the scenes of Australia's rental crisis

image.altText: Stan Grant on Q+A.

items.synopsis: Stan Grant makes an emotional statement at the end of Q+A, announcing he will be stepping away from media commitments following racist abuse, but confirming that he will be back stronger after a break.

title.children: Stan Grant sends a message to his abusers in last Q+A before stepping away

image.altText: A young girl pushes her hair back from her forehead

items.synopsis: Portuguese police set up an exclusion zone in preparation for a search of a reservoir near the resort Madeleine McCann disappeared from in 2007.

title.children: Police to launch search for Madeleine McCann in Portuguese dam

image.altText: A man in a dark suit and red tie.

items.synopsis: ACT Detective Superintendent Scott Moller tells the inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann that he was under pressure from Brittany Higgins, the media and other police members to charge Mr Lehrmann.

title.children: Senior ACT police officer tells inquiry there was 'significant pressure' to charge Bruce Lehrmann

image.altText: The Tesla gigafactory in Nevada

items.synopsis: Batteries could shape Australia's future from mining to assembly. But industry leaders say we need to act quickly to capitalise on the renewables boom.

title.children: In the old fossil fuel heartlands of Australia, a new kind of industry is being built

image.altText: A dark-skinned soccer player points and shouts towards stands during a game. Light-skinned player from another team next to him

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Thor actor Ray Stevenson dies, and Real Madrid calls racist incident a hate crime. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Richmond players have been called to a meeting at the AFL club this morning where they'll reportedly be told Damien Hardwick is quitting as coach. Hardwick is the current longest-serving coach in the league, having won three premierships since taking over at the Tigers in 2010. Collingwood coach Craig McRae worked as an assistant to Hardwick for several seasons. He's told Fox Sports the timing has taken him by surprise. "A bit of shock to be honest, particularly this time of year, round 10," McRae said. "But having worked with [Damien ], he's an incredible coach and he's his own person and I think the Richmond Footy Club will hopefully — if it's true, it hasn't been announced yet has it — I'm sure the Richmond Footy Club will salute him well if it is the case."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Damien Hardwick reportedly stepping down as Richmond AFL coach

props.alt: Damien Hardwick (left) lifts the AFL Premiership Cup with Trent Cotchin (right) both with their arms raised in celebration after winning the grand final

children.content: (AAP: Julian Smith)
Richmond players have been called to a meeting at the AFL club this morning where they'll reportedly be told Damien Hardwick is
quitting as coach
Hardwick is the current longest-serving coach in the league, having won
three premierships
since taking over at the Tigers in 2010.
Collingwood coach Craig McRae worked as an assistant to Hardwick for several seasons.
He's told Fox Sports the timing has taken him by surprise.
"A bit of shock to be honest, particularly this time of year, round 10," McRae said.

"But having worked with [Damien ], he's an incredible coach and he's his own person and I think the Richmond Footy Club will hopefully — if it's true, it hasn't been announced yet has it — I'm sure the Richmond Footy Club will salute him well if it is the case."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: TikTok has filed a lawsuit challenging the US state of Montana's new ban on the Chinese-owned video app. Montana is the first US state to ban the app. TikTok argues the ban, which would take effect on January 1, violates First Amendment rights (that's the right to free speech) of the company and its users. The lawsuit also argues the ban is pre-empted by federal law because it intrudes upon matters of federal concern. TikTok also argues Montana is trying to "banish" the app "based on speculative concerns about TikTok's data security and content moderation practices". Former US president Donald Trump tried to bar new downloads of TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat and other transactions in 2020, which the companies said would have effectively barred use of the apps, but a series of court decisions blocked the bans from taking effect.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: TikTok sues the US state of Montana for banning the Chinese-owned app

children.content: (AP: Matt Slocum)
TikTok has filed a lawsuit challenging the US state of Montana's new ban on the Chinese-owned video app.
Montana is the first US state to ban the app.
TikTok argues the ban, which would take effect on January 1,
violates First Amendment rights (that's the right to free speech) of the company and its users
The lawsuit also argues the ban is pre-empted by federal law because it intrudes upon matters of federal concern.
TikTok also argues Montana is trying to "banish" the app "based on speculative concerns about TikTok's data security and content moderation practices".

Former US president Donald Trump tried to bar new downloads of TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat and other transactions in 2020, which the companies said would have effectively barred use of the apps, but a series of court decisions blocked the bans from taking effect.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A US judge has entered a not guilty plea for the man charged with stabbing four students to death in Idaho. Bryan Kohberger, 28, was arrested late last year and charged with burglary and four counts of first-degree murder in connection with the killings of Madison Mogen, Kaylee Goncalves, Xana Kernodle and Ethan Chapin at a rental home near the University of Idaho campus. Kohberger declined to enter pleas with his attorney telling the judge they would "stand silent" at this time. The judge entered not guilty pleas on Kohberger's behalf. The trial, expected the last six weeks, has been scheduled to start on October 2.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Judge enters not guilty pleas for suspect in stabbing deaths of four students

props.alt: Bryan Kohberger walks into the courtroom in prison orange clothes, with a man in a suit walking behind.

children.content: (The Moscow-Pullman Daily News via AP: Zach Wilkinson)
A US judge has entered a not guilty plea for the man charged with stabbing four students to death in Idaho.
Bryan Kohberger, 28, was arrested late last year and
charged with burglary and four counts of first-degree murder
in connection with the killings of
Madison Mogen
Kaylee Goncalves
Xana Kernodle

at a rental home near the

Kohberger declined to enter pleas with his attorney telling the judge they would "stand silent" at this time. The judge entered
not guilty pleas
on Kohberger's behalf.
The trial, expected the last six weeks, has been scheduled to start on October 2.

image.altText: Pedestrians crossing a city road in all different directions. A man walking toward the camera wears a blue surgical mask

items.synopsis: As the temperature drops, Australia is approaching its fifth COVID wave. This is what it could look like.

title.children: Australia is approaching its fifth Omicron COVID-19 wave. What can we expect this time?

image.altText: Halle and Alison

items.synopsis: Draft international guidelines on polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) highlight how weight stigma — being judged or discriminated against because of our weight — can prevent women from getting the proper treatment and support they deserve.

image.altText: Two men exit the doors of a court building. The lawyer is wearing a suit, the other man is wearing shorts and a jumper.

items.synopsis: In sentencing former national rock climbing coach Stephen Mitchell, a judge said he had abused a "gross disparity of age and power".

title.children: Former Australian rock climbing coach sentenced to more than 13 years in prison for sex offences

image.altText: Tina Arena stands looking at the camera on a stage with dramatic lighting and a piano in the background.

image.altText: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy disembarks French government plane.

items.synopsis: Western nations have stepped up the provision of weapons to Ukraine. While this will be key to helping Ukraine confront the Russians, there are two other aspects of combat power which are even more vital, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's secret ingredient in war with Russia isn't weapons

image.altText: US Air Force F-16 fighter jets in the sky.

items.synopsis: The destructive power and global availability of F-16 jets is expected to help break the land warfare slog and shift the balance Ukraine's way, but it's unlikely that will happen anytime soon.

image.altText: A picture of the tiktok logo, which looks like a musical note, with a silhouette of a person holding a phone.

items.synopsis: TikTok files a lawsuit challenging the state of Montana's new ban on use of the Chinese-owned short-video app.

title.children: TikTok sues US state of Montana after it moved to ban app

image.altText: Meta logo in background in focus with blurry silhouette heads in foreground.

items.synopsis: Meta is hit with a record 1.2 billion euro ($1.9 billion) fine by its lead privacy regulator in the European Union for its handling of user information and given five months to stop transferring users' data to the United States.

title.children: Meta hit with record $1.9 billion fine over transfer of users' data to United States

image.altText: Fish swim around coral

items.synopsis: A first-of-its-kind data portal being unveiled today will allow marine and armchair scientists to take an in-depth look at what lives on the sea floor around Australia.

title.children: Scientists take a look into the deep with online mapping tool revealing marine life on ocean floors

image.altText: a cafe worker serves customers

items.synopsis: Australia's industrial relations system is like Catch-22. You can't have a pay rise until productivity improves. And productivity can't improve until you get a pay rise, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The great productivity con. Why your pay isn't keeping up with inflation

image.altText: A birds eye view of a coastal town.

items.synopsis: As house prices cool off in some parts of the country, this town on the Capricorn Coast is still growing as people flock from south-east Queensland.

title.children: Why the small coastal town of Yeppoon is 'still in the boom cycle'

image.altText: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi goes to shake hands with PNG Prime Minister James Marape.

items.synopsis: India's leader will address a rally which is expected to draw a crowd of up to 20,000 people who are hoping to catch a glimpse of the prime minister and listen as Mr Modi — a powerful orator — extols the virtues of the Australia-India relationship.

title.children: Thousands from Indian diaspora expected to flock to see Prime Minister Narendra Modi during Australia visit

image.altText: Two women stand in front of black-and-white photos of rock climbing.

items.synopsis: A court has heard Stephen Mitchell created a web of lies and fabrications in order to sexually assault six little girls who trusted him — this week, the former rock climbing instructor was finally punished.

image.altText: United Fire Fighters Union Secretary John Oliver standing in front of a union media screen.

image.altText: Cradle Mountain Master Plan, cable car

items.synopsis: The Cradle Mountain Cableway is in serious doubt after the Commonwealth withdraws $30 million in funding from the project because the Tasmanian government missed a deadline.

image.altText: A closeup of a chilli lime margarita cocktail with a bottle labelled chill lime agave on the table  in front of a bar.

items.synopsis: Hidden near the banks of the Murray River in northern Victoria is a small distillery batting way above its average on the global scale.

title.children: Small town wins big at international spirits competition scoring gold for its agave

image.altText: Blues and orange colours flecked with the stars.

items.synopsis: Sonification is a way to understand astronomical data through sounds. These experts say it's also a good way to understand the mechanics of outer space.

title.children: What does a galaxy 'sound' like? Sonification is a way for more people to engage with astronomy

image.altText: A young woman wearing Berry Springs Tavern staff attire holding a steak sandwich and chips on a plate

items.synopsis: Pubs in Australia's Top End are filling all bar positions this tourist season following a years-long, COVID-induced workforce shortage. It comes as changes to working holiday visas take effect in northern Australia.

title.children: Top End pubs see 'complete flip' on labour shortage after backpacker visa change

image.altText: A man leans on railings along the River Murray.

items.synopsis: Tourism operators on South Australia's River Murray say they are suffering from a "flood hangover" after the state government's voucher program fell short of a full revival.

title.children: 'Flood hangover' hampering River Murray tourism revival

image.altText: People stand in the remains of a burned out building.

items.synopsis: A blaze tears through a school dormitory in Guyana at night, killing at least 19 students and injuring several others.

title.children: Fire tears through school dormitory in Guyana, killing 19 children

image.altText: Printed black and white emails lay on a table with large black boxes redacting text.

items.synopsis: A Treasury investigation into the impact of a PwC tax expert's use of confidential information — sold to clients seeking to minimise tax — could lead to the firm being referred to the Australian Federal Police, the assistant treasurer warns.

title.children: More hard questions about contracts of controversial consulting firm to be asked at Senate Estimates

image.altText: A man wearing a hockey mask stands with his hands in the pocket of his black hoodie. Behind, across a bay, a Qantas plane taxies

title.children: 'You can have a boot full and just drive straight out': Former airport worker was importing cocaine for cartels

image.altText: Brisban inner subrub house rooftops

items.synopsis: In Brisbane, just 10.9 per cent of rental homes are available for less than $400 a week, while the ACT has the smallest share of rentals available for under $400 per week at just 1.8 per cent.

title.children: It's official: Australia's quickly running out of affordable rentals

image.altText: In this concept image, a stadium shines brightly in Hobart under an pink evening sky.

items.synopsis: Tasmania's contentious Gunns pulp mill was made a project of "state significance" but it was never built. What will it mean for Hobart's AFL stadium?

title.children: Will making Hobart's AFL stadium a 'project of state significance' give it a leg up?

image.altText: A grieving mother surrounded by family.

items.synopsis: Jason Kennison's family has paid tribute to an "amazing son, amazing brother, amazing uncle" who "suddenly fell ill" while descending Mount Everest on Friday morning.

title.children: Mum recalls telling mountaineer son 'I'll always love you' before his death on Mount Everest

image.altText: A young woman holding up an anti-fracking sign in front of another woman wearing hiking gear

items.synopsis: Police were called after dozens of protesters stormed the finish line in protest of the NT government's green-lighting of fracking in the Beetaloo Basin.

image.altText: Stock image of a woman holding her head in her hands.

items.synopsis: The Escaping Violence Payment wait time period has dropped by 27 days.

title.children: People can get one-off domestic violence payments within six days

image.altText: Noel Payne stands astride a rusty old motorbike in a backyard, holding the swept back handlebars, wearing a shirt with flames on

items.synopsis: A court has heard Walpeup man Noel Payne was violent and abusive towards his wife and another woman who lived at his property before he was murdered in 2020. His wife Rebecca Payne is to be sentenced for his murder.

title.children: Woman to be sentenced for murdering abusive husband with spiked lemon biscuits

image.altText: A young woman holds a two-year-old girl in her arms, with her child holding a positive pregnancy test in her hands.

items.synopsis: When Kirsty Bryant received a uterus transplant in January — after her mother donated hers — she did not expect to fall pregnant so soon, with her new baby now growing in the same womb that carried her.

title.children: 'Surreal' news as Kirsty falls pregnant just weeks after nation's first uterus transplant — using her mum's womb
